parts: Identify these subsets of processes which processors multiplex using context switching. These are the smallest units of execution that can be run by a program.
The Dining Philosophers Problem, which can be used to simulate deadlock between threads, was solved using semaphores by this Dutch computer scientist
In addition to stopping deadlock, scheduling algorithms also try to stop this condition, in which a process cannot complete because the scheduler is denying it CPU time or memory that it requires.
Name this first Treasury Secretary of the United Sates who was shot to death in a duel with Aaron Burr.

Alexander Hamilton was a leader of this early political party, which opposed the Democratic Republicans. This party's platform included the creation of a national bank and maintaining good relations with Britain.
Hamilton's scheme to bolster the nation's credit was given this name. It involved taking in old bonds and issuing new ones that match the face value of the old bonds.

Name this class of material that has both holes and electrons as charge carriers. They have abnormally small band gaps which allow them to transfer from an insulative state to a charge carrying state.

These zero-dimensional semiconductor structures are useful in super-resolution imaging for their high resistance to photobleaching. Varying the size of the crystal and the band gap allows tuning of their emission wavelength.
Typical quantum dots are made with cores this Metal's Selenide or Sulfide. Usage of this heavy metal in semiconductors is being heavily reduced due to its toxicity.

Identify this philosophical work which ends by advocating " the greatest dissemination of power consistent with efficiency; but the greatest possible centralization of information, and diffusion of it from the centre."
On Liberty was written by this Englishman, whose other works include The Subjection of Women.
The first chapter of On Liberty accuses this philosopher, the author of Course on Positive Philosophy, of "aim[ing] at establishing... a despotism of society over the individual."
Identify this comedy in which Pisthetaerus takes over the city of Cloudcuckooland and blocks the offerings of the people below to the gods.
The Birds is a work by this ancient Greek playwright, who depicted the women of Greece attempting to end the Peloponnesian war using a sex strike in his Lysistrata.

This term refers to a passage in an ancient Greek play in which the chorus directly addresses the audience. In The Birds, the chorus threatens to shit on the judges if the play doesn't win the City Dionysia.
Name this man who painted the Beethoven Frieze as well as The Kiss, which like many of his works from the 1900's uses gold leaf and a strange collage of rectangles.

Klimt painted two portraits of this wife of a businessman. Now at the Neue Galerie, that first portrait was for a time the most expensive painting ever sold and was at the center of a legal battle by the subject's niece Maria Altmann.

Klimt also created the mosaics Expectation and Tree of Life as part of this frieze for a palace in Brussels. The mosaics feature a recurring spiral motif on the tree and what appears to be the couple from The Kiss seen from a different angle with slightly different clothing.

answers: Name this novella in which the title character meets Amaso Delano, the captain of the Bachelor's Delight, who saves the title character from murder at the hands of his ship's crew.
Typee: A Peep at Polynesian Life or Omoo: A Narrative of the South Seas
parts: Name this novella in which the title character meets Amaso Delano, the captain of the Bachelor's Delight, who saves the title character from murder at the hands of his ship's crew.

Melville, the author of Benito Cereno, also wrote the story "Billy Budd" in which the title character has a speech impediment and so resorts to punching, and incidentally killing, this other character.
Melville's first written book  involves his actual experiences in the South Pacific as a captive on Nuku Hiva. Name either that book or its sequel.
Identify this slow ballad, featuring a piano solo despite its composer's proficiency with a different instrument, that was named for its composer's wife Juanita Grubbs.
This jazz saxophonist recorded "Naima" with his quartet including Jimmy Garrison and McCoy Tyner. He also played soprano saxophone for the album My Favorite Things.
Coltrane sings the title of this album, which begins with a gong strike. This album consists of the four parts: Acknowledgement, Resolution, Pursuance, and Psalm.

answers: Labarna I [prompt on "Hattusili I" or "Labarna II" because of recent scholarship, I guess]
parts: That letter was found in this empire's capital of Hattusa and was addressed to Suppiluliuma I. This Anatolian civilization is commonly attributed with being the first with widespread iron production.

During this battle, Hittite chariots routed the Ra division but the Ptah division forced the Hittite infantry into the namesake city. King Muwatallis and Pharoah Ramses II signed the first peace treaty here.
This man is the traditional first king of the Hittites and founder of their Old Kingdom. This figure may actually just be his successor, Hattusili I, sometimes called the second of this name.

Name this 60s rock band that never achieved commercial success but is considered on of the most influential bands of the 60s. Its critically successful songs include 'Pale Blue Eyes' and 'Venus in Furs.'

This front man for the Velvet Underground had a very successful solo career after the group's split. His album "Transformer" included critically successful songs such as "Vicious" and "Walk on the Wild Side."
Name the less critically successful Lou Reed album that consists of an hour of feedback loops and noise music that eschews the conventions of good taste.

answers: Targowica Confederation [accept Konfederacja targowicka or Targovicos konfederacija]
parts: Name this man better known for fortifying Saratoga against Burgyone and becoming the chief of the engineering corps during the American Revolutionary War.

Koxciuszko led a revolt in this country that had already lost land to Prussia, Austria, and Russia. This would lead to the third and final partition of this country after the Praga district massacre in Warsaw.

This group of Polish magnates appealed to Russia to overturn the reforms of the May 3rd Constitution. Russia sent an army to aid this group to defeat the King and Sejm, but only to partition more land for itself.

answers: Smooth ER or Smooth Endoplasmic Reticulum
parts: Identify this abdominal organ, which develops fibrotic scar tissue in cirrhosis. One of its primary functions is producing bile.

Hepatocytes are responsible for detoxification; thus it makes sense that this organelle is highly developed in hepatocytes. Unlike a related organelle, it has no ribosomes on its surface, and it synthesizes lipids and steroids.

The detoxification and drug metabolism processes in the liver are performed by a family of cytochrome enzymes given this name. It gets its name from the peak wavelength of a complex created when CO is added to it.
Identify this epistolary novel about a girl enslaved by the nobleman Mr. B. The title character's virtue is rewarded because she falls in love with Mr B as he keeps forcing himself on her.
Samuel Richardson's Pamela was satirized in this man's Shamela. He also wrote a novel about the brother of Pamela who is repeatedly hit on by Lady Booby, entitled Joseph Andrews.

This literary critic heavily skewers Pamela in his The English Novel: An Introduction. This British critic also published Literary Theory: An Introduction and got into trouble for calling Kingsley Amis a drunken anti-semite.
Identify this collection of seven Anglo-Saxon kingdoms that ruled Britain until Egbert of Wessex managed to consolidate them in the late 800s.

Wessex was one of the main members of the Heptarchy. This king of Wessex defeated the Danes at the Battle of Ashdown, created a network of fortresses called Burhs, and translated Boethius' Consolation of Philosophy
This other member of the Heptarchy had its capitol at Tamworth and was ruled by a line of kings including Penda and Offa.

answers: national epic [prompt on just epic, accept synonyms for "national"]
parts: Name this item that wears a purple dress in a poem addressed to a "Mignonne."
"Mignonne, allons voir si la Rose" was written by this "Prince of Poets" and leader of La PlÃ©iade who wrote in the French Renaissance.
Ronsard's La Franciade was intended to fulfill this role for France. These poems include Scotland's Ossian and Poland's Pan Tadeusz.
Identify this Shinto solar deity, the sister of Susanoo and Tsuki-yomi who hid in a cave after Susanoo went rampaging through heaven.
Amaterasu was the daughter of this deity, who was unable to retrieve his wife from the underworld. Amaterasu was born from his left eye.
Izanagi and Izanami created the island of Onogoro-shima by churning the seas with one of these objects named Ame-no-nu-hoko.
This man called for such odd instruments as turntables and radio receivers in his Imaginary Landscapes. He's probably better known for a piece consisting entirely of silence, 4'33".
This man wrote his Poeme electronique for a pavilion at the 1958 World's Fair designed by Le Corbusier. He also composed Density 21.5 to mark the invention of the platinum flute.

This American serial composer combined the synthesizer with both live and recorded soprano in his Philomel. Also noted for his contributions to theory, he examined the state of the avant-garde composer in an article for High Fidelity called "Who Cares if You Listen?"
Identify this psychotherapist and author of On Becoming a Person, who developed a humanistic form of treatment in which a patients positive potential is realized, called client-centered therapy.

Rogers viewed this as the product of the fact that everyone exists at the center of a world of changing experience. Allport defined it using dispositions, and it is the subject of the MMPI and Meyers-Briggs indicators.

This other American humanist psychoanalyst attempted to apply existentialism to psychoanalysis. He was a friend of Paul Tillich drew a distinction between "free sex" and "free love" in his Love and Will.
Identify these chemical reagents which speed up reactions by lowering the activation energy.
A catalyst that has a different phase than the molecules it acts upon is given this name. This type of catalyst is often mixed with a support in order to increase its surface area.
This process uses an Iridium complex as a catalyst in order to synthesize acetic acid. This process replaces the less efficient Monsanto process.

This Nazi era religion that opposed the "German Christian" Faction 's attempts to remove Jewish influence from Christianity. The author of the "First they came" poem, Martin Niemoller was a leader of this group.
This other leader of the Confessing Church gave a radio speech denouncing Hitler and warning against a cult of the Fuhrer. He was later executed at Flossenburg for his part in the July 20 conspiracy.

This Pope who reigned during WWII signed the Reichskonkordat with the Nazi Government to give the Catholic Church rights in Germany. He issued Mit Brennender Sorge in response to the many violations of the treaty.
